item.title: Evangelical Deficiencies and the Rise of Transgenderism [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: David introduces a short new series with transgender affirming testimony offered to the Tennessee legislature by an ACLU attorney and a minister who is a “follower of Jesus.” In the mini-series David will explain two doctrinal deficiencies within evangelicalism over the last 200 years that have made their testimony perfectly logical to so many. Only as these two doctrinal deficiencies are addressed will our nation’s present course change.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Seeing “Transgender Care” for Minors and Parental Rights Correctly [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Today David draws on Abraham Kuyper to explain an “ah ha” moment he had last week regarding previous episodes discussing legislation in multiple states seeking to end “transgender care” for minors. It was the moment in which Kuyper’s distinction between religion for the sake of God vis-à-vis the sake of man came into focus and became practical and real.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Are the Means and Purposes of Christian Political Engagement Today Idolatrous? [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Today David reflects on recent conversations with Christian policy makers regarding transgender legislation and on the growing emphasis by Christians on restoring “civil liberty” in light of what Hosea, Isaiah, and Augustine have to say. What might they tell us about the way Christians now “do” politics and their motivations for engagement, and what might that mean in the years to come?
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: The Government’s New Role: Promoter of Dignity [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: In A Christian Manifesto, Francis Schaeffer connected Rousseau’s worldview to ours by the term “sociological law.” Today, David explains how that connection works and why it has become the basis for an increasing number of government officials (and others) to think that law is to “promote dignity.” Promoting dignity is at the heart of the battle over transgender legislation.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: ‘Christian’ Legislation in Multiple States Puts Cancel Culture in Control [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Legislation in multiple states will take on the issue of gender affirming care. Christians will support it and not realize that the reasons given for it deny the existence of any real law. This means real parental rights can no longer be based on real law. That leaves cancel culture in driver’s seat to cancel the parental rights and civil liberties that Christian so greatly prize. Welcome to world Rousseau’s civil religion created when the evangelical gospel went Gnostic!
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Christian Nationalism: Is Rousseau’s ‘Religion’ the Foundation of Christian Nationalism? [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: The root of Christian Nationalism lies in Jean-Jacques Rousseau’s interpretation of Jesus’ mission in coming into a pagan world. It reads like what many evangelicals preach and believe. His reinterpretation of the Gospel paved the way for a purely secular state. It allowed religion to exist for the sake of the state, not God.
item.author: David Fowler
item.itunes:author: David Fowler

item.title: Christian Nationalism: The False View of Civil Government on Which It Rests [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Christian nationalism arises out of justification for civil government and civil liberty grounded in bad theology. David uses Scripture and Abraham Kuyper to explain how a current Christian publication on this subject rests more on Rousseau’s contract theory of just government than on what the Bible says about God.
item.author: David Fowler
item.itunes:author: David Fowler

item.title: Why Christianity Has Rendered Itself Irrelevant [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Christianity is no longer relevant to civil law and government. Many Christians want it to be or become relevant again. Today David uses Abraham Kuyper to explain why Christianity has made itself irrelevant. Without that understanding, we will have no clue why it will remain irrelevant despite all our Christian political action.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Christians Who Destroy Christianity Trying to Protect It [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: In today’s episode David will explain why leading evangelicals, in the name of protecting religion, presumably Christianity, are instead destroying it. The distinction between objective and subjective Christianity was on full display in the letter submitted to two United States Senators by Presbyterian minister, Dr. Kim Park, president of the National Association of Evangelicals regarding the Respect for Marriage Act.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Is Your Politics “Theocentric”? [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: What is a theocentric worldview? What is a theocentric view of law and civil government? Today David will explain what it is, what happened last week that exposed some of his non-Theocentric thinking, and what effect theocentric thinking should have on the way we look at politics.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Building Blocks—A Necessary Perspective [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Today David explains how Psalm 37:1-5 applies when things are going wrong all around us. It provides the necessary perspective for those who see the need to restore what few people even know they have lost, the Western Legal Tradition.

item.title: Building Blocks—Are Christians Allying Themselves with ‘Deeds of Darkness’? [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: The Apostle Paul says Christians are not to “have fellowship with the unfruitful works of darkness,” but are to “expose them.” Yet, when it comes to legislation being filed around the country opposing “gender affirming care” for minors, many Christians are being tempted to join those whose worldview is darkness and, therefore, ultimately unfruitful. David exposes the “dark” worldview to which many are falling prey by using observations by J. Gresham Machen taken from Christianity and Liberalism.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Building Blocks—Where Does Science “Fit” Today in Law and Policy [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Last week we learned how common law is rooted in a Biblical cosmology. Today David uses excerpts from interviews with Jeff Shafer and legislation being filed around the country pertaining to transgenderism to explain why science not only can be of no real help on this legal issue, but how its current use is undermining law and parental rights in particular.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Building Blocks—The ‘Nature of Law’ We Once Believed [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: In June, the United States Supreme Court decided a 2nd Amendment controversy and reversed Roe v. Wade citing William Blackstone’s Commentaries on the Laws of England as authority. After you listen, you will be astounded to learn how much the cosmology of Genesis Chapters 1 through 3 informed Blackstone’s description of the nature of law. You will know what even most Christian lawyers don’t know about law.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Building Blocks—Finding the “Beautiful” in Law [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: When faced with a difficult task—like restoring the Western Legal Tradition—convictions based on truth are essential. But what will inspire the courage necessary to the task: truth alone or truth that is beautiful. If the latter, what can be said that makes law beautiful to anyone?

item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Building Blocks—Don’t Be Gullible [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: If the Western Legal Tradition is to be re-built, then it is good to know what the “other side” sounds like, what arguments they make. Today, David takes audio clips of arguments made by a Republican state legislator who is a lawyer and professing Christian to expose humanistic legal thinking. His arguments swayed other Republicans into not supporting legislation that allowed a man and woman to marry without having to first get permission from the government.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Building Blocks—Understanding the Two Kinds of Legal Systems and Why That’s Important [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Few today would know the difference between common and positive law legal systems, positive laws and negative laws. Even fewer would think the difference matters—law is law. Today David uses part of conversation between Choc Knox and Jason Farley from Choc Knox Unplugged to explore the difference and why it is vitally important to a country of immigrants.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Building Blocks—Resisting the “Hobnail boot” of Totalitarianism [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: We live in a totalitarian condition disguised by the fact we still hold elections. Today, with help from Theology Pugcast, David explains why that is so and what must be recovered in Christian thinking if civil liberty is to be rebuilt.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Building Blocks [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: David begins a new series today by taking a story from a headline this week about Governor Youngkin “restoring parental rights” and explaining why he is doing no such thing. With this story, Matt Walsh’s explosive story about Vanderbilt’s transgender procedures on minors, and the help of Dr. Tom Price from Theology Pugcast, David explains the first building block.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins—Foundation for Hope [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: To close this series on the ruins of America’s legal tradition, rooted in the Western Legal Tradition, David explains the surest foundation any Christian can have that it can be restored. The foundation for that sure and certain hope, he explains, rests on a covenant seldom discussed in evangelicalism.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins—Getting a Right Conception of the Constitution [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: In today’s episode, David uses a conception of the Constitution expressed by five U.S. Supreme Court justices in the 1992 decision, Planned Parenthood v. Casey, that affirmed the abortion holding in Roe v. Wade. He weaves it, along with a common every day legal practice involving millions of Americans a year, into the theme on which the whole story of the Bible rests.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins- Is Restoring Law and the Constitution Futile Obedience? [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: In the penultimate episode of this series, David addresses head on the prevailing pessimism for any expectation for cultural progress if Jesus is indeed returning soon. Is obedience then simply for the sake of personal sanctification? A close look at the thread of the Noahic covenant running from Genesis through the epistles gives us a different perspective that should attend our current labors.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins—Respect for Marriage Act and Eschatology [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Eschatology affects the way we look at legislation. Today David explains how eschatology affects the way Christians will look at the Respect for Marriage Act pending in Congress and an even more fundamental issue—what does pursuing the Kingdom of God and His righteousness look like in this context.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins: Why Do Christians Think Like Losers? [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: It is hard to work toward restoring our nation’s ruined legal and constitutional foundation when today’s prevailing eschatology says those efforts are divinely appointed to fail. The Christian eschatology that produced the Western Legal Tradition was rooted in the belief that by the death, resurrection, and ascension of Jesus Christ all things were being made new. What changed? Is there any Scripture we can point to that objectively assures us our restorative labors in this world are not in vain? Absolutely!
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins—The Right Perspective is Necessary [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Last week David explained how a change in eschatology undermined the foundations of Western Legal Tradition. Today he begins to lay the foundation for how we need to think about time and history if that foundation is to be restored. He explains how an evolutionary view of time and history has replaced that which the Bible says is true of God and creation.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins—What Does Eschatology Have to Do with Law? [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Eschatology can be a contentious subject in evangelicalism. But few realize the critical role it played in development of the Western Legal Tradition. Even fewer know why today’s prevailing eschatology undermined and helped lead to the loss of the Western view of law. Don’t be “left behind” in your knowledge of the rise and fall of the Western view of law.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins—Is the ‘Western Legal Tradition’ Gone? [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Colleges increasingly minimize or fail even to teach Western Civilization, and that means the Western Legal Tradition on which our law and Constitution rest are jettisoned too. But what is that tradition and is it even important now? Does it relate to anything the U.S. Supreme Court does now?
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins—Justice Thomas Explains How Common Law Thinking Works [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: How is the Constitution relevant to our modern problems especially if it is going to be interpreted based on the common law meaning of the words at the time it was ratified? For example, how does that work when the “arms” referenced in the Second Amendment envisioned muskets? David walks us through Justice Clarence Thomas’ explanation of how the justices think about the common law, and then show how we all think the same way every day.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins- Justice Thomas Show How to Repair the U.S. Constitution [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: Today, David takes Clarence Thomas’ majority opinion in the Court’s decision protecting the 2nd Amendment from encroachment by the state of New York to demonstrate a right understanding of common law and its importance to the Constitution. That five other Justices signed onto the opinion makes understanding it vitally important.
item.author: FLF, LLC
item.itunes:author: FLF, LLC

item.title: Restoring the Ruins— What is Common Law and Why Even Care? [God, Law, and Liberty]
item.description: In 20th century, teaching common law fell into disrepute in law schools. In June, the U.S. Supreme Court based two constitutional decisions on the common law. Today, David explains why Christian should care about common law and insist that an understanding and appreciation of it be diffused throughout the church.
item.author: David Fowler
item.itunes:author: David Fowler
